dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: ...and uh, they've actually just sued Apple, right? Like, this little-known company out of Austin. Yeah, another one, whatever. Some patent troll, I guess? Happens every week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...and uh, they've actually just sued Apple, right? Like, this little-known company out of Austin. Yeah, another one, whatever. Some patent troll, I guess? Happens every week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based in Austin, Texas, Fintiv is a virtually unknown entity in the tech world... In February, two months after Fintiv sued Apple...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, see, it's not just a patent troll. This company, Fintiv, it used to be called Mozido. Does that ring a bell?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, see, it's not just a patent troll. This company, Fintiv, it used to be called Mozido. Does that ring a bell?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Fintiv used to be known by a different name, Mozido... According to an amended certificate of incorporation filed with Delawares secretary of state, Mozido has changed its name to Fintiv.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Mozido? Oh, wait. Wasn't that the one, uh, with the big fraud allegations? Like, the "financial Theranos"?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mozido? Oh, wait. Wasn't that the one, uh, with the big fraud allegations? Like, the financial Theranos?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Forbespublished a detailed article about Mozido in July 2016 calling the company the financial industrys Theranos.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! So, Michael Liberty, the founder, he's just been indicted for a massive investment scam. Accused of siphoning off, like, seventy million dollars for personal use, you know, lavish spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! So, Michael Liberty, the founder, he's just been indicted for a massive investment scam. Accused of siphoning off, like, seventy million dollars for personal use, you know, lavish spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SEC claimed Liberty raised $55 million from individuals who thought they were investing in Mozido and diverted a large portion of those funds for his personal use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. So they just changed the name, sued Apple, and hoped no one would notice? That's, uh, pretty bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. So they just changed the name, sued Apple, and hoped no one would notice? That's, uh, pretty bold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. The name change happened right before the SEC charged Liberty. But here's the kicker: Mozido itself was never actually charged, just him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. The name change happened right before the S E C charged Liberty. But here's the kicker: Mozido itself was never actually charged, just him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Charlie Wiggs, president of Fintiv, signed the Delaware filing changing Mozidos name to Fintiv a few days after the Securities & Exchange Commission charged Liberty last year of defrauding 200 individual investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: But the optics, I mean, come on. Bad optics is an understatement. So, this guy's still involved? Liberty, I mean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the optics, I mean, come on. Bad optics is an understatement. So, this guy's still involved? Liberty, I mean?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liberty, who has pleaded not guilty to the criminal charges filed against him and has previously denied wrongdoing, is one of Fintivs shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: He is. He's pleaded not guilty, obviously, but he still maintains a stake in Fintiv. And get this, his cousin, Stan Liberty, and this Mike Love character, they're both directors now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He is. He's pleaded not guilty, obviously, but he still maintains a stake in Fintiv. And get this, his cousin, Stan Liberty, and this Mike Love character, they're both directors now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Liberty, who has pleaded not guilty to the criminal charges filed against him... is one of Fintivs shareholders... Mike Love, who played a big management role at Mozido for years and worked closely with Liberty, is a director of Fintiv. So is Michael Libertys cousin, Stan Liberty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Family business, then. And they're suing Apple over some patent they picked up in Korea?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Family business, then. And they're suing Apple over some patent they picked up in Korea?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The patent Fintiv is using to sue Apple lists inventors in South Korea, and Mozido acquired the patent when it purchased the South Korean entity that owned it in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. That's the whole strategy now, apparently. Their chairman, Adolfo Salume, he's, like, all about protecting their IP, building out the patent portfolio. He says lawsuits are a last resort, but...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. That's the whole strategy now, apparently. Their chairman, Adolfo Salume, he's, like, all about protecting their I P, building out the patent portfolio. He says lawsuits are a last resort, but...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Adolfo Salume, Fintivs chairman, says the company has formed a division to consolidate its patents and enforce them, preferably through licensing... a last resort is a lawsuit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: But they went straight for Apple. Color me surprised. It's just... it's always about the patents when the core business goes south, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they went straight for Apple. Color me surprised. It's just... it's always about the patents when the core business goes south, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker B
dialogue_turns.text: I guess so. But it just shows, you know, how these entities, they can pivot, repackage, and, um, try to leverage assets even after, like, massive scandals. It's kinda wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I guess so. But it just shows, you know, how these entities, they can pivot, repackage, and, um, try to leverage assets even after, like, massive scandals. It's kinda wild.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild or just incredibly predictable? I don't know, B. Seems like the same old story to me.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild or just incredibly predictable? I don't know, B. Seems like the same old story to me.
